texts.shortText: Laterally flattened, smooth-bodied, shrimp-like amphipod, best recognized by its obligate association with limpets. Colour pale translucent green with red eyes. Antennae equal and about 20% body length; nippers small and more of less equal, with elongate, rectangular hand. Last 3 pairs of abdominal appendages (uropods) with two equal branches, almost devoid of spines. End of telson rounded or slightly notched.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Cape Agulhas.

Well known for its apparent obligate association with large limpets, particularly being found under shells of Cymbula oculus, C. granatina, C. miniata and C. compressa, as well as Scutellastra tabularis. Usually occur in male/female pairs within the mantle (gill) cavity of the limpet. The sizes of the amphipods is correlated with that of the host limpet. Thought to be territorial and to defend their host habitat (the limpet) against other individuals of its own species.
Feed on faeces of the limpet host and probably also on algal fragments scraped from the rocks by the limpet’s radula.

Males copulate with females and inseminate the eggs when they are released into the marsupium, which is situated between the legs of the female. There they develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.

The only regional species in the genus and best identified by its unusual habitat. Another amphipod, Apohyale grandicornis, is also sometimes found under limpets exposed during low tide, but this is a casual relationship, and the amphipods leave their host during high tide (see that species entry for a description of Apohyale). In Apohyale the second nipper is also greatly enlarged in males and the last pair of uropods has only one short branch.

Barnard, JL (1978). Redescription of the amphipod, Calliopiella michaelseni Schellenberg from South Africa, with comparison to a new genus from the Pacific Ocean. Annals of the South African Museum 75: 33–40.

Branch, G (1975). The ecology of Patella from the Cape Peninsula, South Africa. 5. Commensalism. Zoologica Africana, 10, 133–162.

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum (p. 40).
